results.title: Farm Newsreel No. 1
results.brief_description: This newsreel film features agricultural activities throughout Victoria, Australia. Activities featured include hop harvesting in Myrtleford, tobacco harvesting in Ovens Valley, onion harvesting in Colac, and silage distibution in Upper Pakenham.

results.title: The Mallee Research Station
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Colin Webb
results.brief_description:
This film, made by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was created to promote the ingenuity of agricultural scientists working at the Mallee Research Station in Walpeup, Victoria.

The film highlights the research station’s development of wheat production, sheep breeding and pasture improvements. It contains some wonderful examples of farm machinery and farming techniques of the era.

results.title: [Agnotes Advertisement: 1]
results.brief_description:
Victoria’s Department of Agriculture (now Agriculture Victoria) produced Agnotes, a series of reference material for the industry with the aim to disseminate expert advise for best agricultural practices.

This advertisement was designed to increase the uptake of the Agnotes by farmers. It is one of many commercials produced for the Department of Agriculture.

results.title: A Working holiday
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Jack Keane
results.brief_description: Hop picking in Victoria; seasonal workers gather from all parts of Australia for six weeks to harvest hops in the rich Ovens Valley. Shows the picking, bagging and weighing of the bags, and transport to the kilns. The weekend break is spent swimming, fishing or sight-seeing in the surrounding Alps.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Jack Keane
results.description: Hop picking in Victoria; seasonal workers gather from all parts of Australia for six weeks to harvest hops in the rich Ovens Valley. Shows the picking, bagging and weighing of the bags, and transport to the kilns. The weekend break is spent swimming, fishing or sight-seeing in the surrounding Alps.
description_for_label: Hop picking in Victoria; seasonal workers gather from all parts of Australia for six weeks to harvest hops in the rich Ovens Valley. Shows the picking, bagging and weighing of the bags, and transport to the kilns. The weekend break is spent swimming, fishing or sight-seeing in the surrounding Alps.

results.title: Fiercely independent
results.brief_description:
Lindenow South (the Swamp Hawks) have been fighting off attempts to force their amalgamation with other clubs for years. The “Swampies” recognise their football club as the heart of their community.

Thank you to Alan Thorpe, Laurie Edwards, Des Edwards, and Lindenow South Football Club.

TRANSCRIPT

I was fifteen when I started playing for Lindenow South an’ have played with both teams…played for Lindenow, played with Lindenow South an’ it seemed a shame that the people in the towns dislike each other so much, as far as the Football goes. But it stems back to years and years ago, Lindenow were the rich an’ the mighty sort of thing an’ they decided they wanted to amalgamate with our Club an’ we didn’t want to an’ they’ve been tryin’ now for about twenty odd years, tryin’ to get us together but never the twain should meet, sort of thing.

They’ve tried everything…they tried there a few years back they put a dummy President and Sec’etary in an’ took our coach an’ several of our players. But there’s one thing they couldn’t take an’ never will take from the “Swampies” an’ that’s the Swamp Hawks spirit. They’ll never get it.

I don’t know whether there’s really that much rivalry, I guess we perhaps don’t like ‘em much. It’s been just the way it is, like…even my grandma, she used to follow the footy, she actually died at the footy, like she took a bit of heart attack, she was barracking for her grandson playing and she was real keen, very keen. We had some good supporters over the years and especially some of the ladies with their bloody umbrellas, their pointy umbrellas…good weapons.

It’s the hub of the town. See, we’ve got Netball, which is connected with Football an’ we’ve got Tennis, Cricket, all going on, but if your Football Club goes all those other Clubs will just die.

We loose our Football team, we loose our identity…no Lindenow South and that’s how the cookie crumbles.

results.title: High and wild
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)
results.brief_description: High and Wild is the latest video from the Wilderness Society’s ongoing education program. It traces the journey of eight students and their teacher from Melbourne’s Kingswood College on what, for most, was their first wilderness experience. Shot on location in Victoria’s Wonnangatta-Moroka National Park “High and Wild” captures the students’ experience as they explore a variety of issues surrounding wilderness - such as alpine grazing logging, flora/fauna protection, outdoor recreation, Aboriginal and World Heritage values.

results.title: Green Fingers: Weed Control
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Weed Control’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to control weeds in the home garden. Cantrill shows a range of methods for managing weeds, including hoeing, mulching and herbicides, accompanied by a narrator who explains the benefits and correct techniques of each method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Planting Evergreens
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Planting Evergreens’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to correctly plant evergreen trees and shrubs in your garden, accompanied by a narrator explaining the method and techniques. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.
description_for_label: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Planting Evergreens’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to correctly plant evergreen trees and shrubs in your garden, accompanied by a narrator explaining the method and techniques. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Born in the sun
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and John Heyer
results.brief_description: Shows the development of the dried fruits industry at Mildura from the time of Deakin’s irrigation bill, and highlights the part irrigation has played. Includes a dramatised extract of an Alfred Deakin speech. The film shows climatic setbacks which the industry has experienced. Illustrates the harvesting, processing and distribution of the fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian National Film Board and John Heyer
results.description: Shows the development of the dried fruits industry at Mildura from the time of Deakin’s irrigation bill, and highlights the part irrigation has played. Includes a dramatised extract of an Alfred Deakin speech. The film shows climatic setbacks which the industry has experienced. Illustrates the harvesting, processing and distribution of the fruit.
description_for_label: Shows the development of the dried fruits industry at Mildura from the time of Deakin’s irrigation bill, and highlights the part irrigation has played. Includes a dramatised extract of an Alfred Deakin speech. The film shows climatic setbacks which the industry has experienced. Illustrates the harvesting, processing and distribution of the fruit.

results.title: Goodness - it's milk!
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit
results.brief_description:
This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, promotes the dairy industry by proclaiming the benefits of drinking milk.

The film opens with some lovely footage of a couple exploring the Blue Dandenongs, including a milkbar with signs for ‘Peter’s Ice-Cream’, ‘Herald’, and ‘Four ‘n’ Twenty Pies’, where they order two tall glasses of milk.

The film then shows scenes of schoolchildren, a patient and nurse in a hospital and a domestic kitchen, while the narrator describes the health benefits of milk. The film finishes with footage of the dairy industry, from the farm to industrial pasteurising and bottling processes, and finally home delivery.
